posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked:
Our team typically does not color our robot, but for future seasons, we are exploring additional options. It appears to be straightforward to anodize aluminum using the resources available in the lab.

A DIY Step-by-Step Guide on How to Anodize Aluminum | SendCutSend](https://sendcutsend.com/blog/diy-anodizing-in-10-steps/).

Is there an advantage to anodizing parts versus powder coating, and how does this affect bearing tolerances?

link_counts.title: A DIY Step-by-Step Guide on How to Anodize Aluminum | SendCutSend

posts.name: diego
posts.cooked: Powder coating isn't reliable if done improperly, resulting in uneven thickness—it truly depends on the skill of the person doing it. Always plug any bearing holes before finishing. Our team plans to tackle spray-painting next year since it looks great when executed well and isn’t very expensive. Consider it as a viable alternative.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Sulfuric acid, lye, and lead are all dangerous materials that pose serious health and environmental risks when exposed. DIY anodizing can be extremely hazardous because these chemicals react violently with each other, potentially causing explosions, burns, or toxic fumes. Handling such dangerous substances requires specialized knowledge and proper protective gear. Disposing of the waste generated from anodizing is another significant concern, as it may contain harmful residues that require strict disposal regulations. On the other hand, powder coating or spray painting offer a safer and more environmentally friendly alternative for achieving a durable finish on metal surfaces. These methods eliminate the risk of chemical exposure and simplify the disposal process since the waste typically consists of inert paints and solvents.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: They are not something I would let kids be around, but there are standard procedures for neutralizing bases and acids—it’s why we’re all dragging boxes of baking soda from one end of the country to the other. Maintaining car batteries used to require measuring acid and water levels and strength, potentially topping them up.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of your text, formatted as a single, coherent paragraph while preserving the original meaning and maintaining proper grammar and punctuation:

Anodizing parts offers no benefits related to weight or tolerance compared to powder coating, according to FIRST Robotics Competition standards. While this method avoids harsh chemicals, it's not advisable for FRC teams to perform anodizing in-house due to potential risks and complexities involved.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: Many of those chemicals are restricted in California. Rattle-can with proper surface preparation is the way I recommend.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: Two other options are both low-weight and durable.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Co-Head Mentor 3658
posts.cooked: My teams have painted every robot I’ve been part of over the past 6 seasons. I built a DIY powder coating station in my garage using an old hotdog warmer from a high school cafeteria. While powder coating isn’t particularly hard, it does require practice and is much cheaper than other finishing methods. I’ve noticed that powder coating has helped us win quality and industrial design awards, especially when it comes to the color of the robot. However, painting, or "rattle-canning," tends to be unreliable due to flaking. I highly recommend anyone interested in improving their robot’s appearance to learn the art of powder coating—it really makes a difference, as evidenced by the awards we’ve received.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Chase Eid
posts.cooked: MaxTube works exceptionally well with paint. I believe it’s because it’s manufactured in such a way that causes small imperfections on the aluminum, allowing the paint to adhere more effectively compared to untreated (unsanded) sheet metal.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
Sure! Here's the cleaned-up version:

I don’t deny that powder coating is great; this is its primary benefit. However, I’m providing additional information on cerakote products. Cerakote offers a “cold” series, which dries quickly without an oven. The main difference between this series and others is the cure time. Additionally, Cerakote provides various series for users who prefer oven-cured finishes or those who choose that option themselves.  

I don’t work for Cerakote, nor have I personally used their products before.  

**Edit:** Cerakote typically requires only a 1-mil (.001-inch) thick coating, which is minimal in terms of application.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked: Anodizing is thinner than powder coating, with multiple levels such as hard anodizing, which offers higher hardness but fewer color options. Powder coating is thicker and requires masking bearing holes. When choosing between materials, consider factors like color availability and surface preparation. Black anodizing is simpler but offers fewer colors, while Cerakote provides thinness, diverse colors, and durability, though it needs proper surface prep for adhesion.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Cerakote drying requires several hours before it becomes tack-free and takes approximately five days to fully cure. Additionally, its distinctive odor, reminiscent of burning urinal cakes, poses a severe inhalation risk. While I apply Cerakote for recreational and profitable uses, I refrain from recommending it for robot components, despite its impressive appearance in tests.

Anodizing aluminum involves harsh chemical processes followed by dyeing and sealing, which I do not endorse. DIY anodized titanium is achievable through water, baking soda, and low-voltage electrical components. Achieving a desirable blue color required a voltage of 30V.

For my robot project, after minimal preparation, the body was rattle-cased. It impresses online but shows wear-upclose during competitions. This trade-off between aesthetics and practicality is common among team projects.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked: You can also use vinyl to wrap parts, such as those used for cars and buses. While not as durable as some alternatives, vinyl offers both patterned prints and solid colors. Depending on various factors, certain parts may be wrapped once they are on the robot.

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
Was there any surface preparation done on this Air-Cure Cerakote? I didn't even know such a product existed.  

We had to perform Oxide Blast, which required PPE and a certain type of filtration, followed by wiping clean before spraying, and then placing it in the oven.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
It’s crucial to use super-duper clean bare metal for optimal results. To achieve this, follow these steps:

- Degrease the material thoroughly.
- Sandblast or abrade any rough areas.
- For stubborn parts, use a propane torch to remove oxides.
- Degrease again to ensure cleanliness.

While waiting one minute might work for steel, aluminum oxidizes too rapidly; therefore, you must spray it immediately after removing its natural oxide layer. Additionally, the application needs to be extremely thin, so ensuring a perfect surface finish is paramount. The material used, such as Cerakote, hides absolutely nothing, guaranteeing durability.

posts.name: JohnD 3322
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of your text:

Check for a local shop that offers anodizing. They may provide free anodizing services, often referred to as “in-kind” sponsorship. Don’t expect it to come quickly; typically, we send a few tubes early in the season and then machine them after anodizing. This process results in a two-tone finish with shiny holes. Additionally, you can use Sharpie for touch-ups or restoring colors.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked:
Anodizing removes a thin layer of material from parts. When parts become too thin, they must be replaced. However, if a part is anodized multiple times, its tolerances will not be affected significantly.

We are fortunate to have a local anodizing company located in Indianapolis that supplies parts to several Central Indiana teams. Big thanks to Colors Inc., an amazing company!

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Anodizing does not merely remove material but instead converts part of the base metal into an oxide layer. This process increases the part's size rather than reducing it. For instance, applying a 0.002-inch thick anodizing coat results in the part expanding outward by 0.001 inches, with the original material contributing 0.001 inches to the oxide layer. This expansion is subtle but significant in precision applications.

When repairing anodized components, especially titanium racks, it's crucial to understand that anodizing typically alters dimensions at the nanometer level, often undetectable to the naked eye. Aluminum anodizing can add thickness ranging from 0.004 to 0.005 inches, which might compromise critical fits like pin and bearing connections or create tight-spaced bolt holes. This raises concerns about whether manufacturers compensate for anodizing-induced growth through intentional etching.

The original post seems to conflate anodizing with common etching processes. Anodizers may adjust etching to match the expected dimensional changes during anodizing, aiming to achieve the desired final size. Conversely, some parts might be manufactured under tighter tolerances, relying on the oxide layer to bring them back into specification.

Notably, some parts used in anodizing baths may dissolve over time, particularly if made from less durable materials. This highlights the importance of selecting appropriate substrates for anodizing processes to ensure longevity and compatibility.

In summary, anodizing does not remove material but modifies it by converting a portion into an oxide layer, leading to dimensional expansion. Proper application requires understanding these effects to avoid compromising component integrity and fit.
